newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Ninety-two states to sign Ottawa landmine treaty.
newsitem.headline: Ninety-two states to sign Ottawa landmine treaty.

text.p: Ninety-two countries have signed the Declaration of Brussels preparing a first-ever landmine ban treaty to be signed in Ottawa, Canada in December, diplomats at a Brussels conference told Reuters on Friday.

The organisers of the four-day Conference on a Global Ban on Anti-personnel Mines were due to make a formal statement about the number of countries who have signed the Brussels Declaration at the conference's closing news conference later today.
The signatories include African, central American and some Asian countries as well as all European Union nations with the exception of Greece and Finland.
Greece refuses to sign because of territorial disputes with Turkey while Finland refuses because of its long border with Russia.

A total of 115 countries have been taking part in the Brussels talks. Signature of the Brussels Declaration was a pre-condition for countries to be allowed to join talks in Oslo, Norway, in September where the exact wording of the Ottawa treaty will be negotiated.

Thirty-six other delegations took part in the Brussels talks as observers. They included Cuba, Greece, India, Indonesia, Iran, Israel, Libya, Pakistan, the Palestinian Authority, Turkey and the United States.
Russia and China, the main producers of landmines, did not take part in the negotiations at all.

The landmine talks, which started in Ottawa at the end of 1996, are set to lead to the signing of the first-ever treaty to ban the production, use, stockpiling and transfer of anti-personnel landmines.
The United States will not sign because it favours separate United Nations-sponsored landmine talks in Geneva.

The Geneva Conference on Disarmament, which requires consensus, is not expected to produce a landmine ban for some years. However, it appointed a special co-ordinator on the subject on Thursday, signalling agreement by Third World states that it be tackled on its own and no longer tied to deadlocked nuclear topics.

The International Campaign to Ban Landmines (ICBL), the main anti-mine lobby group, backed by over 1,000 non-governmental organisations, has severely criticised the United States' efforts to undermine the Ottawa Process.
It said on Thursday that the United States, Greece and Turkey stod as the only NATO countries not on board the Ottawa talks.
